question_text: Is there a strict hierarchy of width classes within NC^2?
answer: YES - WIDTH-NC^2(n^k) STRICT_SUBSET WIDTH-NC^2(n^(k+1)) for all k >= 1

main_theorem.name: Width Hierarchy Theorem (NC^2)
main_theorem.statement: For all k >= 1: WIDTH-NC^2(n^k) STRICT_SUBSET WIDTH-NC^2(n^(k+1))
main_theorem.interpretation: NC^2 has infinite internal structure stratified by polynomial width degree

width_n.name: VECTOR-SUM
width_n.why_width_tight: Cannot sum n numbers with fewer than n wires

width_n2.name: MATRIX-MULT
width_n2.description: Multiply two n x n matrices
width_n2.why_width_tight: n^2 output entries, each needs partial sums

width_n3.name: MATRIX-INVERSE
width_n3.description: Compute inverse of n x n matrix

width_nk.name: k-TENSOR-CONTRACT
width_nk.why_width_tight: k-tensor has n^k entries to process

stratification.statement:
NC^2 = UNION_{k=1}^{infinity} WIDTH-NC^2(n^k)

where the union is STRICT at each level:
WIDTH-NC^2(n^1) STRICT_SUBSET WIDTH-NC^2(n^2) STRICT_SUBSET ... STRICT_SUBSET NC^2

corollaries.name: NC^2 is not monolithic
corollaries.statement: NC^2 has infinite internal structure based on width
corollaries.significance: Problems in NC^2 have varying 'hardness' measured by width

corollaries.name: Width-complete problems exist at each level
corollaries.statement: For each k, there exist WIDTH-NC^2(n^k)-complete problems
corollaries.significance: Natural hierarchy of complete problems within NC^2

corollaries.name: Connection to space complexity
corollaries.statement: WIDTH-NC^2(n^k) corresponds to SPACE(k * log n) within NC^2

stratification.complete_picture:
THE NC^2 WIDTH LANDSCAPE

+------------------------------------------------------------------+
|                           NC^2                                    |
|  (log^2 depth, poly width)                                       |
+------------------------------------------------------------------+
|                                                                   |
|  WIDTH-NC^2(n)     STRICT_SUBSET                                 |
|    - VECTOR-SUM                                                   |
|    - Element-wise ops                                            |
|                                                                   |
|  WIDTH-NC^2(n^2)   STRICT_SUBSET                                 |
|    - MATRIX-MULT                                                  |
|    - Graph algorithms                                            |
|    - Contains NL (Phase 75)                                      |
|                                                                   |
|  WIDTH-NC^2(n^3)   STRICT_SUBSET                                 |
|    - MATRIX-INVERSE                                               |
|    - Linear system solving                                       |
|                                                                   |
|  WIDTH-NC^2(n^k)   STRICT_SUBSET  ...                            |
|    - k-tensor operations                                         |
|                                                                   |
+------------------------------------------------------------------+

phase_31.connection: Same diagonalization technique proves width hierarchy

phase_35.connection: NC^2 is coordination complexity; width hierarchy = coordination hierarchy within NC^2

phase_58.connection: Depth separates NC^1 from NC^2; now width stratifies NC^2 internally

phase_72.connection: Width = space; width hierarchy in NC^2 mirrors space hierarchy

phase_73.connection: L is the log-width fragment; NC^2 has polynomial-width fragments

phase_74.connection: NL fits at the log-width level; now we see the full width spectrum

phase_75.result: NL STRICT_SUBSET NC^2 via width gap
phase_75.connection: The gap between NL (log-width) and NC^2 (poly-width) is now STRATIFIED

for_circuit_complexity.insight: Circuit complexity has THREE independent resources: depth, width, size
for_circuit_complexity.consequence: Lower bounds can target any of these resources
for_circuit_complexity.new_technique: Width lower bounds may be easier than size lower bounds

for_parallel_computing.insight: Parallel algorithms have width requirements independent of time
for_parallel_computing.consequence: Some parallel algorithms need more 'memory lanes' than others
for_parallel_computing.practical: Hardware design should match problem width requirements

for_space_complexity.insight: Width hierarchy in NC^2 mirrors space hierarchy
for_space_complexity.consequence: Circuit width and Turing machine space are truly equivalent resources
for_space_complexity.unification: Further evidence for the Rosetta Stone (Phase 72)

for_coordination.connection: CC_log = NC^2 means coordination hierarchy = width hierarchy

for_p_vs_np.insight: Width hierarchy gives new attack angle
for_p_vs_np.question: Does NP require super-polynomial width?
for_p_vs_np.hope: If P has bounded width but NP doesn't, we have separation

new_questions.question: Are there WIDTH-NC^2(n^k)-complete problems for each k?
Does the width hierarchy extend to NC^3 and beyond?
What is the width requirement for NC^2-complete problems?
Can width lower bounds prove new circuit lower bounds?
Is there a width-efficient universal NC^2 circuit?

key_insights: NC^2 is NOT monolithic - it has infinite internal structure
Width hierarchy mirrors space hierarchy (Phase 72 connection)
Matrix operations provide natural witnesses at each level
WIDTH-NC^2(n^k) corresponds to SPACE(k * log n) within NC^2
This fills the gap between NL (log-width) and full NC^2 (poly-width)
building_blocks_used: Phase 75: NL STRICT_SUBSET NC^2 via width gap
